chapter.title: Developer Install and Setup
chapter.para: This chapter is designed to provide simple step-by-step instructions on how to set up a development machine to begin working with Kuali Rice on Mac OS X or Windows platforms with a MySQL database.

The steps to install and setup a developer machine with Kuali Rice are:
Database setup - Please refer to the Installing and Configuring the Database Management System section of this guide to install and configure your database.
Install & configure required software - Please refer to the Common Setup section of this guide to install and configure software required by both development and standalone server environments.
Set up your Development Environment
Install and Configure Rice
Launch the Sample Application

section.title: Development Environment
section.para: Eclipse is the open source Java Integrated Development Environment (IDE) that most Kuali application developers use and setup for Eclipse is outlined here. Another popular IDE used by some Kuali developers is IntelliJ IDEA. Instructions here will be for Eclipse.

section.title: Eclipse installation
section.para: Download the latest version of Eclipse from the eclipse.org download page:
Once you have downloaded the zip file, unzip it to a location of your choosing. Inside of that directory will be an executable named "eclipse" that you can use to start Eclipse.

section.title: Defining a Workspace
section.para: When Eclipse starts up for the first time it will ask you to identify a workspace to use. Enter a location of your choosing for your workspace. All of the projects that you check out from source control will be imported into that workspace.

section.title: Verify that Eclipse is Using Java 6
section.para: To verify that Eclipse is using Java 6, you will need to open the Eclipse "Preferences" pane. You do this on Windows by going to "Edit -> Preferences". On Mac OS X you nativate to "Eclipse -> Preferences".
Once on the Preferences pane, navigate to "Java -> Installed JREs". Ensure that Java 6 (or 1.6) is selected. See screenshot below:

section.title: Disable DTD, JSP, TagLib, and XML Validators
section.para:
The Kuali Rice code has some XML and Tag libraries with schemas and DTDs that do not validate well when being built inside of Eclipse. To eliminate Eclipse build errors, please disable these.
Open the Eclipse "Preferences" window.
Navigate to "Validation".
Deselect the following checkboxes under "Build".
DTD Validator
JSP Content Validator
JSP Syntax Validator
Tag Library Descriptor Validator
XML Schema Validator
XML Validator
XSL Validator
Click "OK.
When prompted to do a full rebuild, click "Yes".

section.title: Install Subclipse
section.para: Subclipse is a Subversion plugin for Eclipse. If you plan on checking out the Kuali Rice source code or any example code from the Kuali subversion repository, then it would be useful to install subclipse to manage this within Eclipse.

Subclipse is installed within Eclipse using Eclipse's update site feature with the following steps:
Click on the "Help" menu and select "Install New Software...".
This will open up the "Install" screen. Click on the "Add..." button.
This should bring up a dialog that allows you to add the Subclipse update site.
Type a name of "Subclipse" and a location like "http://subclipse.tigris.org/update_1.6.x" and click the "OK" button.
This will populate the Install screen with 3 different components that can be installed.
Check all three check boxes:
Click the "Next" button.
You should see the list of items that will be installed, click "Next" again.
On the "Review Licenses" screen, select "I accept the terms of the license agreements" and click the "Finish" button.
At this point Eclipse will begin downloading and installing Subclipse.
If you see a message that says "Warning: You are installing software that contains unsigned content", click "OK".
When asked to restart Eclipse, click "Restart Now".

section.title: Checkout the Kuali Rice Project
section.para:
First, you will need to add the Kuali Rice Subversion repository to your Subclipse so that you can check out the project. Follow the steps below to do this:
In Eclipse, navigate to "Window -> Open Perspective -> Other..." and the select "SVN Repository Exploring" on the following window:
This will open up the SVN perspective in Eclipse.
From the "SVN Repositories" view, click the button to add a new repository.
On the subsequent screen, enter the following for the URL: https://test.kuali.org/svn/rice
Click the "Finish" button.
If you are prompted to accept the digital certificate, select "Accept Permananently". Since Kuali Rice is licensed under the open source ECL 2.0 license, you should not be asked for a password to access the source code.
The Rice repository should now be added to your "SVN Repositories" view.
Navigate to tags/rice-${project.version} in the "SVN Repositories" view and right client on rice-${project.version}.
Select "Checkout..."
On the resulting "Checkout from SVN" dialog leave the defaults and click "Finish".
This will begin checking out Kuali Rice ${project.version} from Subversion.

section.title: Compile Rice and Populate Maven Repository
section.para:
At this point, the Kuali Rice project may note compile in Eclipse yet. We will work on resolving this and getting everything to compile properly next. In order to accomplish this, we will do the following:
Populate your local maven repository with all Kuali Rice required jars.
Compile your copy of the the Kuali Rice project.
Ensure that the Kuali Rice project is compiling properly in Eclipse.

section.title: Populating the Maven Repository
section.para:
To populate the maven repository, execute the following steps:
Open a Terminal or Command prompt.
Change directory to your copy of the Kuali Rice project.
Type the following at the command line: mvn test-compile
This will begin a process which will download all Kuali Rice dependencies as well as compiling the source code within. Depending on the speed of your Internet connection, this could take ten minutes or more than 20 minutes as all of the dependencies are downloaded, so please be patient.

section.title: Set up Eclipse for Maven
section.para:
In order to ensure that Eclipse can read from the Maven repository, we have to define the M2_REPO classpath variable:
Open your Eclipse "Preferences" screen.
Navigate to "Java -> Build Path -> Classpath Variables".
Click the "New..." button.
Create a new Classpath variable with the name of M2_REPO and a value pointing to your Maven repository directory (<user home/.m2/repository).
Click "Ok".
When prompted about a full rebuild, click "Yes".

section.title: Validate that the Kuali Rice project is compiling in Eclipse
section.para:
Now that our Maven repository has been populated and weve set Eclipse up to be able to read from that Maven repository, let's ensure that the Kuali Rice project is compiling properly in Eclipse.
Navigate back to Eclipse.
Find the rice-${project.version} project and right click on it; select "Refresh". Eclipse should attempt to build the project at this point and (once it has completed) all errors on the Rice ${project.version} project should be gone.
If the errors on rice-${project.version} aew not gone after performing the above steps, do the following:
Right-click on the rice-${project.version} project and select "Close Project".
Right-click on the rice-${project.version} project and select "Open Project".
Click on the rice-${project.version} and the open the "Project" menu at the top of the screen.
Select "Clean..." and ensure that only rice-${project.version} is checked in the list on the resulting screen; click "OK".
After the clean is executed, the rice-${project.version} project in Eclipse should be error free.

section.title: Creating the Database
section.para:
To install the database using mave, complete the following steps:
Open a Terminal or Command prompt.
Change directory to your copy of the Kuali Rice project.
Change into the directory for the "master" data set: cd db/impex/master
Verify that Maven can connect to your database instance running locally:
MySQL: mvn validate -Pdb,mysql -Dimpex.dba.password=[dbapassword]
If the 'root' user does not have a password (which is the default on a new MySQL install), drop the '-Dimpex.dba.password' parameter from all MySQL commands or use 'NONE' for the password: mvn validate -Pdb,mysql
or mvn validate -Pdb,mysql -Dimpex.dba.password=NONE
Oracle: mvn validate -Pdb,oracle -Dimpex.dba.password=[dbapassword]
If you are using Oracle and validation fails with an error about "com.oracle:ojdbc14:jar:10.2.0.3.0", follow the instructions Installing and Configuring the Database Management System section of this guide to install Oracle's JDBC driver into your local maven repository.
Load the Data Set for your database running locally:
MySQL: mvn clean install -Pdb,mysql -Dimpex.dba.password=[dbapassword]
Oracle: mvn clean install -Pdb,oracle -Dimpex.dba.password=[dbapassword]
You should get the following message at the end of the process [INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------ [INFO] BUILD SUCCESS [INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------
You will have a database called 'rice' that you can access with username 'RICE', password 'RICE'

section.title: Launching the Sample Application
section.para:
An Eclipse launch script is provided in the project that you can use to launch a Jetty server that will load the web application. To luanch the application and access the initial portal for the application, do the following:
Navigate back to Eclipse.
Find the rice-${project.version} project
Expand the project in the "Project Explorer" so that you can see the files contained within.
Navigate to rice-sample-app ->
Right-click on the "Jetty 7 [sampleapp].launch" file and select "Run As -> 1 Jetty 7 [sampleapp]".
If you have configured everything successfully, this should start up your client web application without any errors.
You can verify that your application started successfuly by going to the following url:
http://localhost:8080/kr-dev
You should see a login screen. Enter the username "admin" and then click the "login" button.
After you login, you should see a screen like the following:

para.emphasis: Congratulations! You have now installed and configured Kuali Rice ${project.version} correctly.

section.para: If you are still having problems, please review the instructions again and see if a step was missed. If not, you can review the archives of our collaboration/user's group list at http://kuali.org/kis/projectTeams/team/111 and post your question to the list (you'll need to join first) for community support if the answer is not found in the archives.
